pli-tv-pvr17:40.3: (): Āpattiyā payogaṃ na jānātīti “ayaṃ āpatti kāyappayogā, ayaṃ vacīpayogā”ti na jānāti, “Āpattiyā payogaṃ na jānāti means he does not know : ‘This offense takes bodily effort; this offense takes verbal effort.’” | Sp.5.424: Āpattiyā na vinicchayakusalo hotīti “imasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ ayaṃ āpattī”ti na jānāti, “Āpattiyā na vinicchayakusalo hoti means he does not know: ‘When there is this action, there is this offense.’”
pli-tv-pvr17:41.3: (): Adhikaraṇānañhi yathāsakaṃmūlameva payogā nāma honti, “For it is just the source of the legal issues that is called effort.”
pli-tv-pvr17:44.3: (): Vattanti sattasu kammesu heṭṭhā catunnaṃ kammānaṃ aṭṭhārasavidhaṃ tividhassa ca ukkhepanīyakammassa tecattālīsavidhaṃ vattaṃ na jānāti, “Vatta: among the seven legal procedures found below, he does not know the eighteen kinds of proper conduct of the four legal procedures or the forty-three kinds of proper conduct of the three kinds of legal procedure of ejection.”
pli-tv-pvr17:45.3: (): Padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ na jānātīti sammukhā kātabbaṃ padaṃ na jānāti. “Buddho bhagavā”ti vattabbe “bhagavā buddho”ti heṭṭhupariyaṃ katvā padaṃ yojeti, “Padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ na jānāti: he does not know the words that are to be done in the presence of. When ‘Buddho bhagavā’ is to be said, having reversed the order, he makes it ‘bhagavā Buddho’.” | Sp.5.325: Anusandhivacanapathanti kathānusandhi-vinicchayānusandhivasena vatthuṃ na jānāti, “Anusandhivacanapatha: he does not understand the basis for the sequence of statements and the sequence of decisions.”
pli-tv-pvr17:49.3: (): Suttaṃ na jānātīti ubhatovibhaṅgaṃ na jānāti. Suttānulomaṃ na jānātīti cattāro mahāpadese na jānāti. Vinayaṃ na jānātīti khandhakaparivāraṃ na jānāti. Vinayānulomaṃ na jānātīti cattāro mahāpadeseyeva na jānāti, “Suttaṃ na jānāti: he does not know the analyses of both Monastic Codes. Suttānulomaṃ na jānātīti: he does not know the four great standards. Vinayaṃ na jānāti: he does not know the Chapters and the Compendium. Vinayānulomaṃ na jānāti: he does not know the four great standards.” Instead of following the commentary, I prefer to understand Sutta in its early usage of Monastic Code, equivalent to the Pātimokkha, and Vinaya as the entire Vinaya corpus, the Monastic Law.
pli-tv-pvr17:50.3: (): Na ca pubbāparakusalo hotīti purekathāya ca pacchākathāya ca akusalo hoti, “Na ca pubbāparakusalo hoti: he is unskilled in what should be said first and what should be said afterwards.”
pli-tv-pvr17:54.1: (): Diṭṭhāvikammāti diṭṭhīnaṃ āvikammāni; laddhippakāsanāni āpattidesanāsaṅkhātānaṃ vinayakammānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ, “Diṭṭhāvikamma means the revealing of views; this is an expression for the revealings through the procedures of Monastic Law that are confessions of an offense.”
pli-tv-pvr17:55.3: (): Anāpattiyā diṭṭhiṃ āvi karotīti anāpattimeva āpattīti desetīti attho, “Anāpattiyā diṭṭhiṃ āvi karoti: the meaning is that one confesses a non-offense as an offense.” Sp.5.425: Cattāro pañca janā ekato āpattiṃ desentīti attho, “The meaning is that he confesses the offense to four or five people together.” Sp.5.425: Vacībhedaṃ akatvā citteneva āpattiṃ desetīti attho, “The meaning is that he confesses the offense by mind, without braking into speech.”
pli-tv-pvr17:148.3: It is not clear why this is considered five rather than six items. The same list recurs in the Bhikkhunī-kkhandhaka, (pli-tv-pvr17:9.1.18), but without “he exposes both shoulders to the nuns” and without any reference to householders. The exposition in the Bhikkhunī-kkhandhaka seems more plausible.
pli-tv-pvr17:173.3: (): Pasāretā hoti no sāretāti mohetā hoti, na satiuppādetā; codakacuditakānaṃ kathaṃ moheti pidahati na sāretīti attho, “Pasāretā hoti no sāretā: he confuses, does not cause others to remember; the meaning is that, in regard to the speech of the accusers and those who are accused, he confuses, conceals, and does not cause them to remember.”
pli-tv-pvr17:196.4: (): Uddesenāti pañcasu pātimokkhuddesesu aññatarena uddesena, “Uddesena: through reciting any of the five recitations of the Monastic Code.” | Sp.5.458: Voharantoti kathayanto; tāhi tāhi upapattīhi “adhammaṃ dhammo”tiādīni aṭṭhārasa bhedakaravatthūni dīpento, “Voharanto: speaking; proclaiming, from wherever it arises, the eighteen bases for schism, that is, proclaiming what is contrary to the Teaching as the Teaching, etc.”
pli-tv-pvr17:202.3: (): vinidhāya diṭṭhiṃ kammenāti tesu adhammādīsu adhammādayo eteti evaṃdiṭṭhikova hutvā taṃ diṭṭhiṃ vinidhāya te dhammādivasena dīpetvā visuṃ kammaṃ karoti, “Vinidhāya diṭṭhiṃ kammena: he has the view that ‘These are not the Teaching’, etc., but he misrepresents that view, proclaiming them as the Teaching, etc., and he then does a separate legal procedure.”
pli-tv-pvr17:230.3: (): Pariṇāmetīti niyāmeti dīpeti katheti, “Pariṇāmeti: he specifies, he proclaims, he speaks.” The basic meaning of pariṇāmeti is to change, often a change towards ripening or maturity. Here it seems to be used synonymously with byākaraṇā, the corresponding word used in the question. I render it accordingly.
pli-tv-pvr17:246.3: Sp.5.467: Asamannāharantoti kiccayapasutattā vandanaṃ asamannāharanto, “Asamannāharanto: not paying attention to the paying respect because of being occupied with a task.”
